awd_titl_txt: The Determinants State-Level Immigration Law in New Immigrant Destinations
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Title:  Immigration Law in New Destination States
PIs:  Hana Brown (Wake Forest University) and Jennifer Jones (University of Notre Dame)

This project examines why some states have adopted anti-immigrant laws while others have embraced newcomers with more supportive incorporation initiatives. The investigators examine immigration law in the U.S. South, a prominent new immigrant destination region marked by radically different state-level approaches to immigration governance. The researchers draw on interviews, media analysis, and archival data to understand the origins of different enforcement regimes.  Findings will clarify patterns of access to key institutions that affect immigrant incorporation with significant implications for communities, organizations, and state entities that work with new immigrant populations. More broadly, this project will reveal the forces that drive a patchwork policy system that increasingly grants subnational entities jurisdiction across a range of legal issues. 

In the United States and globally, immigration laws exist at the intersection of two prevailing trends: the criminalization and racialization of non-citizens and the devolution of legal enforcement to subnational authorities. Dominant explanations for variation in state immigration law emphasize the role of partisan politics, political ideology, and demographic change. However, these paradigms cannot satisfactorily explain recent lawmaking patterns in new immigrant destinations. Comparing two cases (Alabama and Georgia) where conservative politics and a growing Latino population gave rise to omnibus anti-immigrant laws to two cases (Mississippi and North Carolina) where the same forces did not have the same result will help to specify the dynamics that drive the criminalization of immigrants and the extension of states' punitive powers. The researchers examine the role of interracial activist networks in thwarting enforcement efforts. Specifically, the project examines Black-Latino coalitions as (1) cultural brokers, race makers who strategically shape beliefs about Black-Latino commonalities and diffuse these racial schemata across media, legal, and political forums and as (2) organizational brokers, liaisons who forge or activate networks across established legal movements (labor, civil rights) to heighten the political risks of supporting anti-immigrant laws and pressure lawmakers to reject such reforms. Findings will help elucidate how social context and non-state actors shape immigration law and specify the central role that advocacy organizations and legal processes play in the racial formation process. As the country becomes majority-minority, such findings will also have important implications for our understanding of the role of the legal context in shaping immigrant incorporation and racialization in the contemporary United States.

por.por_cntn:
In recent years, immigrant settlement patterns in the U.S. have witnessed a staggering transformation. Newcomers once settled overwhelmingly in traditional urban gateways like Los Angeles and New York, but over the last 30 years they have landed in new destination areas like the South and Midwest. Researchers have investigated the effects of these shifts on local communities, intergroup relations, and public policy. Far less studied, however, is the vibrant and diverse field of immigrant-serving organizations that emerged in response to this demographic growth. These organizations have emerged as crucial lifelines for immigrants and as central players in immigration politics in new immigrant destinations.  They link noncitizens to citizens and policymakers and play an instrumental role in immigrants’ integration into host societies and their ability to make rights claims. 

The field of immigrant rights organizing has exploded since the early 1990s, but these new organizations vary in their visions, strategies, and effectiveness. In places like Mississippi, the primary immigrant-serving organizations have mounted a unified struggle for immigrant rights that embraces immigration as a racial justice issue.  The coalition has proven instrumental in the defeat of over 300 anti-immigrant bills in the state legislature. In Alabama, immigrant-serving organizations have adopted different visions of immigration and intergroup relations.  They remain loosely affiliated and sometimes at odds, even in the face of Alabama’s HB56, the nation’s most restrictive state immigration policy. Even in the same city, immigrant-serving organizations may adopt radically different approaches to their work.  How do immigrant-serving organizations develop humanitarian and political strategies in new destinations?  How do immigrant organizations understand immigration, race, integration, and pluralism?  What consequences do organizational approaches have on state and local immigration policy?  This project, a collaboration between Dr. Hana Brown (Wake Forest University) and Dr. Jennifer Jones (University of Illinois, Chicago) journeys across the region and across three decades (1990-2020) to answer these questions.

Our findings suggest that one of the most consequential differences across immigrant service and advocacy organizations is their orientation toward race and racism. We identify two broad racialized orientations among immigrant-serving organizations. Organizations that adopt a colorblind orientation characterize immigrants as strivers, replicating a long-standing bootstrap narrative of upward mobility that resists comparison between immigrants and native-born marginalized communities. This approach perceives the U.S. political system as fundamentally open. On the other hand, organizations that adopt a color-conscious orientation assume that immigration is fundamentally a racial justice issue.  They draw comparisons between the contemporary era of immigration enforcement and past and present discrimination against African-Americans. Unlike colorblind organizations, color-conscious organizations assume that the American political system is characterized by power struggles and inequality.

Although there is variation within each, these two orientations affect how organizations strategize, how they perceive and interact with immigrants, and whether, how, and with whom they form political alliances. Because the colorblind orientation symbolizes inclusion, it attracts donations from resource-rich white communities and allows organizations to provide economic and social assistance to immigrants. Yet, it provides scant room for political coalition building and resists fundamental change in the power dynamics that marginalize immigrant communities and maintain racial hierarchies. The color-conscious approach, however, neglects economic and social integration but encourages immigrant political incorporation and opens the door for interracial political coalitions that can challenge anti-immigrant political movements. These organizational understandings of immigration and race have consequences that are much bigger than the organizations themselves or the communities in which they work, enabling different political futures that for state and national politics. 

This project makes notable contributions to multiple scholarly arenas. First, it contributes to our understanding of immigrant incorporation.  Few topics are as extensively studied in immigration scholarship as the assimilation and incorporation process, yet existing work focuses almost exclusively on individual and national-level determinants of immigrant incorporation.  Absent national institutions for facilitating immigrant incorporation in the U.S., immigrant-serving organizations are key players in immigrant incorporation, channeling resources and opportunities to immigrants and directing policy advocacy.  This study allows us to understand and theorize how these organizations and their distinct approaches affect not only immigrant communities and the public and policy reception new arrivals they receive.  In this age of policy devolution, an understanding of local and state-level immigration dynamics is critical as subnational governments are increasingly policy innovators and sites of instrumental debate and change.

Our findings also speak to race scholarship. With the U.S. poised to become majority-minority in the coming decades, researchers continue to speculate on the position Latinos occupy in the U.S. racial hierarchy. Our results help us understand (a) the dynamics that drive racial change and (b) the political implications of these dynamics. Importantly, our study also shed lights on (c) the role of organizations in mediating between macro-level racialization trends and micro-level lived experiences.
